an2.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an2.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an2.1:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

an2.1:2.3.eng: The fault apparent in this life, and the fault to do with lives to come.

an2.1:2.4.eng: What is the fault apparent in this life?

an2.1:2.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco passati coraṃ āgucāriṃ rājāno gahetvā vividhā kammakāraṇā kārente;
an2.1:2.5.eng: It’s when someone sees that kings have arrested a bandit, a criminal, and subjected them to various punishments—

an2.1:2.6.pli: kasāhipi tāḷente, vettehipi tāḷente, addhadaṇḍakehipi tāḷente, hatthampi chindante, pādampi chindante, hatthapādampi chindante, kaṇṇampi chindante, nāsampi chindante, kaṇṇanāsampi chindante, bilaṅgathālikampi karonte, saṅkhamuṇḍikampi karonte, rāhumukhampi karonte, jotimālikampi karonte, hatthapajjotikampi karonte, erakavattikampi karonte, cīrakavāsikampi karonte, eṇeyyakampi karonte, baḷisamaṃsikampi karonte, kahāpaṇikampi karonte, khārāpatacchikampi karonte, palighaparivattikampi karonte, palālapīṭhakampi karonte, tattenapi telena osiñcante, sunakhehipi khādāpente, jīvantampi sūle uttāsente, asināpi sīsaṃ chindante.
an2.1:2.6.eng: whipping, caning, and clubbing; cutting off hands or feet, or both; cutting off ears or nose, or both; the ‘porridge pot’, the ‘shell-shave’, the ‘Rāhu’s mouth’, the ‘garland of fire’, the ‘burning hand’, the ‘bulrush twist’, the ‘bark dress’, the ‘antelope’, the ‘meat hook’, the ‘coins’, the ‘caustic pickle’, the ‘twisting bar’, the ‘straw mat’; being splashed with hot oil, being fed to the hounds, being impaled alive, and being beheaded.

an2.1:3.2.pli: ‘yathārūpānaṃ kho pāpakānaṃ kammānaṃ hetu coraṃ āgucāriṃ rājāno gahetvā vividhā kammakāraṇā kārenti;
an2.1:3.2.eng: ‘If I were to commit the kinds of bad deeds for which the kings arrested that bandit, that criminal,

an2.1:3.3.pli: kasāhipi tāḷenti, vettehipi tāḷenti, addhadaṇḍakehipi tāḷenti, hatthampi chindanti, pādampi chindanti, hatthapādampi chindanti, kaṇṇampi chindanti, nāsampi chindanti, kaṇṇanāsampi chindanti, bilaṅgathālikampi karonti, saṅkhamuṇḍikampi karonti, rāhumukhampi karonti, jotimālikampi karonti, hatthapajjotikampi karonti, erakavattikampi karonti, cīrakavāsikampi karonti, eṇeyyakampi karonti, baḷisamaṃsikampi karonti, kahāpaṇikampi karonti, khārāpatacchikampi karonti, palighaparivattikampi karonti, palālapīṭhakampi karonti, tattenapi telena osiñcanti, sunakhehipi khādāpenti, jīvantampi sūle uttāsenti, asināpi sīsaṃ chindanti.

an2.1:3.4.pli: Ahañceva kho pana evarūpaṃ pāpakammaṃ kareyyaṃ, mampi rājāno gahetvā evarūpā vividhā kammakāraṇā kāreyyuṃ;
an2.1:3.4.eng: the rulers would arrest me and subject me to the same punishments.

an2.1:3.6.pli: So diṭṭhadhammikassa vajjassa bhīto na paresaṃ pābhataṃ vilumpanto carati.
an2.1:3.6.eng: Afraid of the fault apparent in this life, they do not steal the belongings of others.

an2.1:3.7.eng: This is called the fault apparent in this life.

an2.1:4.1.eng: What is the fault to do with lives to come?

an2.1:4.3.pli: ‘kāyaduccaritassa kho pana pāpako dukkho vipāko abhisamparāyaṃ, vacīduccaritassa pāpako dukkho vipāko abhisamparāyaṃ, manoduccaritassa pāpako dukkho vipāko abhisamparāyaṃ.
an2.1:4.3.eng: ‘Bad conduct of body, speech, or mind has a bad, painful result in the next life.

an2.1:4.4.pli: Ahañceva kho pana kāyena duccaritaṃ careyyaṃ, vācāya duccaritaṃ careyyaṃ, manasā duccaritaṃ careyyaṃ.

an2.1:4.5.pli: Kiñca taṃ yāhaṃ na kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
an2.1:4.5.eng: then, when my body breaks up, after death, won’t I be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell?’

an2.1:4.6.pli: So samparāyikassa vajjassa bhīto kāyaduccaritaṃ pahāya kāyasucaritaṃ bhāveti, vacīduccaritaṃ pahāya vacīsucaritaṃ bhāveti, manoduccaritaṃ pahāya manosucaritaṃ bhāveti, suddhaṃ attānaṃ pariharati.
an2.1:4.6.eng: Afraid of the fault to do with lives to come, they give up bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and develop good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, keeping themselves pure.

an2.1:4.7.eng: This is called the fault to do with lives to come.

an2.1:4.9.eng: So you should train like this:

an2.1:4.10.pli: ‘diṭṭhadhammikassa vajjassa bhāyissāma, samparāyikassa vajjassa bhāyissāma, vajjabhīruno bhavissāma vajjabhayadassāvino’ti.
an2.1:4.10.eng: ‘We will fear the fault apparent in this life, and we will fear the fault to do with lives to come. We will fear faults, seeing the danger in faults.’

an2.1:4.12.pli: Vajjabhīruno, bhikkhave, vajjabhayadassāvino etaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ yaṃ parimuccissati sabbavajjehī”ti.
an2.1:4.12.eng: If you fear faults, seeing the danger in faults, you can expect to be freed from all faults.”

an2.2:1.1.eng: “These two endeavors are challenging in the world.

an2.2:1.3.pli: Yañca gihīnaṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasataṃ cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānuppadānatthaṃ padhānaṃ, yañca agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitānaṃ sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggatthaṃ padhānaṃ.
an2.2:1.3.eng: The endeavor of laypeople staying in a home to provide robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And the endeavor of those gone forth from the lay life to homelessness to let go of all attachments.

an2.2:1.4.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, dve padhānāni durabhisambhavāni lokasmiṃ.
an2.2:1.4.eng: These are the two endeavors that are challenging in the world.

an2.2:2.1.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ dvinnaṃ padhānānaṃ yadidaṃ sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggatthaṃ padhānaṃ.
an2.2:2.1.eng: The better of these two endeavors is the effort to let go of all attachments.

an2.2:2.2.eng: So you should train like this:

an2.2:2.3.eng: ‘We shall endeavor to let go of all attachments.’

an2.3:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekaccassa kāyaduccaritaṃ kataṃ hoti, akataṃ hoti kāyasucaritaṃ;
an2.3:1.3.eng: It’s when someone has done bad things and not done good things, by way of body, speech, and mind.

an2.3:1.4.pli: vacīduccaritaṃ kataṃ hoti, akataṃ hoti vacīsucaritaṃ;

an2.3:1.5.pli: manoduccaritaṃ kataṃ hoti, akataṃ hoti manosucaritaṃ.

an2.3:1.6.pli: So ‘kāyaduccaritaṃ me katan’ti tappati, ‘akataṃ me kāyasucaritan’ti tappati;
an2.3:1.6.eng: Thinking, ‘I’ve done bad things by way of body, speech, and mind’, they’re mortified. Thinking, ‘I haven’t done good things by way of body, speech, and mind’, they’re mortified.

an2.3:1.7.pli: ‘vacīduccaritaṃ me katan’ti tappati, ‘akataṃ me vacīsucaritan’ti tappati;

an2.3:1.8.pli: ‘manoduccaritaṃ me katan’ti tappati, ‘akataṃ me manosucaritan’ti tappati.

an2.3:1.9.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, dve dhammā tapanīyā”ti.
an2.3:1.9.eng: These are the two things that are mortifying.”

an2.4:1.1.eng: “These two things, mendicants, are not mortifying.

an2.4:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekaccassa kāyasucaritaṃ kataṃ hoti, akataṃ hoti kāyaduccaritaṃ;
an2.4:1.3.eng: It’s when someone has done good things and not done bad things, by way of body, speech, and mind.

an2.4:1.4.pli: vacīsucaritaṃ kataṃ hoti, akataṃ hoti vacīduccaritaṃ;

an2.4:1.5.pli: manosucaritaṃ kataṃ hoti, akataṃ hoti manoduccaritaṃ.

an2.4:1.6.pli: So ‘kāyasucaritaṃ me katan’ti na tappati, ‘akataṃ me kāyaduccaritan’ti na tappati;
an2.4:1.6.eng: Thinking, ‘I’ve done good things by way of body, speech, and mind’, they’re not mortified. Thinking, ‘I haven’t done bad things by way of body, speech, and mind’, they’re not mortified.

an2.4:1.7.pli: ‘vacīsucaritaṃ me katan’ti na tappati, ‘akataṃ me vacīduccaritan’ti na tappati;

an2.4:1.8.pli: ‘manosucaritaṃ me katan’ti na tappati, ‘akataṃ me manoduccaritan’ti na tappati.

an2.4:1.9.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, dve dhammā atapanīyā”ti.
an2.4:1.9.eng: These are the two things that are not mortifying.”

an2.5:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I have learned these two things for myself—

an2.5:1.2.pli: yā ca asantuṭṭhitā kusalesu dhammesu, yā ca appaṭivānitā padhānasmiṃ.
an2.5:1.2.eng: to never be content with skillful qualities, and to never stop trying.

an2.5:1.4.pli: ‘kāmaṃ taco ca nhāru ca aṭṭhi ca avasissatu, sarīre upassussatu maṃsalohitaṃ, yaṃ taṃ purisathāmena purisavīriyena purisaparakkamena pattabbaṃ na taṃ apāpuṇitvā vīriyassa saṇṭhānaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
an2.5:1.4.eng: ‘Gladly, let only skin, sinews, and bones remain! Let the flesh and blood waste away in my body! I will not stop trying until I have achieved what is possible by human strength, energy, and vigor.’

an2.5:1.5.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, appamādādhigatā sambodhi, appamādādhigato anuttaro yogakkhemo.
an2.5:1.5.eng: It was by diligence that I achieved awakening, and by diligence that I achieved the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

an2.5:1.6.eng: If you too never stop trying, thinking:

an2.5:1.7.pli: ‘kāmaṃ taco ca nhāru ca aṭṭhi ca avasissatu, sarīre upassussatu maṃsalohitaṃ, yaṃ taṃ purisathāmena purisavīriyena purisaparakkamena pattabbaṃ na taṃ apāpuṇitvā vīriyassa saṇṭhānaṃ bhavissatī’ti, tumhepi, bhikkhave, nacirasseva—
an2.5:1.7.eng: ‘Gladly, let only skin, sinews, and bones remain! Let the flesh and blood waste away in my body! I will not stop trying until I have achieved what is possible by human strength, energy, and vigor.’

an2.5:1.8.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissatha.
an2.5:1.8.eng: You will soon realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life. You will live having achieved with your own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

an2.5:1.9.eng: So you should train like this:

an2.5:1.11.pli: Kāmaṃ taco ca nhāru ca aṭṭhi ca avasissatu, sarīre upassussatu maṃsalohitaṃ, yaṃ taṃ purisathāmena purisavīriyena purisaparakkamena pattabbaṃ na taṃ apāpuṇitvā vīriyassa saṇṭhānaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
an2.5:1.11.eng: “Gladly, let only skin, sinews, and bones remain! Let the flesh and blood waste away in my body! I will not stop trying until I have achieved what is possible by human strength, energy, and vigor.”’

an2.6:1.3.pli: Yā ca saṃyojaniyesu dhammesu assādānupassitā, yā ca saṃyojaniyesu dhammesu nibbidānupassitā.
an2.6:1.3.eng: Seeing things that tighten the fetters as gratifying, and seeing things that tighten the fetters as boring.

an2.6:1.4.pli: Saṃyojaniyesu, bhikkhave, dhammesu assādānupassī viharanto rāgaṃ na pajahati, dosaṃ na pajahati, mohaṃ na pajahati.
an2.6:1.4.eng: When you keep seeing things that tighten the fetters as gratifying, you don’t give up greed, hate, and delusion.

an2.6:1.5.pli: Rāgaṃ appahāya, dosaṃ appahāya, mohaṃ appahāya na parimuccati jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi.
an2.6:1.5.eng: When these are not given up, you’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

an2.6:1.6.eng: You’re not freed from suffering, I say.

an2.6:2.1.pli: Saṃyojaniyesu, bhikkhave, dhammesu nibbidānupassī viharanto rāgaṃ pajahati, dosaṃ pajahati, mohaṃ pajahati.
an2.6:2.1.eng: When you keep seeing things that tighten the fetters as boring, you give up greed, hate, and delusion.

an2.6:2.2.pli: Rāgaṃ pahāya, dosaṃ pahāya, mohaṃ pahāya, parimuccati jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi.
an2.6:2.2.eng: When these are given up, you’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

an2.6:2.3.eng: You’re freed from suffering, I say.

an2.7:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, dve dhammā kaṇhā”ti.
an2.7:1.4.eng: These are the two things that are dark.”

an2.8:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, dve dhammā sukkā”ti.
an2.8:1.4.eng: These are the two things that are bright.”

an2.9:1.1.eng: “These two bright things, mendicants, protect the world.

an2.9:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, dve sukkā dhammā lokaṃ na pāleyyuṃ, nayidha paññāyetha mātāti vā mātucchāti vā mātulānīti vā ācariyabhariyāti vā garūnaṃ dārāti vā.
an2.9:1.4.eng: If these two bright things did not protect the world, there would be no recognition of the status of mother, aunts, or wives and partners of tutors and respected people.

an2.9:1.5.pli: Sambhedaṃ loko agamissa, yathā ajeḷakā kukkuṭasūkarā soṇasiṅgālā.
an2.9:1.5.eng: The world would become dissolute, like goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and hounds and jackals.

an2.9:1.6.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, ime dve sukkā dhammā lokaṃ pālenti tasmā paññāyati mātāti vā mātucchāti vā mātulānīti vā ācariyabhariyāti vā garūnaṃ dārāti vā”ti.
an2.9:1.6.eng: But because the two bright things protect the world, there is recognition of the status of mother, aunts, and wives and partners of tutors and respected people.”

an2.10:1.1.eng: “There are, mendicants, these two entries to the rainy season.

an2.10:1.4.eng: These are the two entries to the rainy season.”
